body.p:
I have been quite unable to answer
your favor of 12th inst until now, having had so
many calls upon my leisure—not the least pleasant
of which was the arrival here of my brother from
London.Your reply with reference to the publishing
of school books is certainly satisfactory so far as
your willingness to unite with me in the undertaking
is concerned, but permit me to say it is less so with
reference to other points. You say when you have
returned from your collecting tour you will be able
to speak more positively as to what can be done in
the matter of printing school books; Am I to
understand that your willingness to go on
depends upon your success in collecting? Please
recollect in the matter of Templo's Grammar that
it is not pleasant for me to appear laboring so
many months in advertisement to produce a
Leão (Templo) and yet not even producing a mouse
nor, perhaps, would it be quite right to withdraw
my advt unless I announced there would certainly
appear jointly that book or one similar—whether
Leesers or Templo's would not much matter so
that we had the one best adapted for schools
that at least one person expects the book Templo

and has paid for it the enclosed will testify.
Please return me Mr Alexander's letter in your
next favor. Do you know him?

I would beg to ask you one question, do
you object to increase “the burthen under which
you stagger” by “going halves” as the school boys
say in producing only Templos book or a
Hebrew Grammar. Without involving either of us
to any large amount we show that we are in the full with the right article and we shall
have made a commencement. I do not say we should
print before you return “about Purim time”
but I do think that before you commence your
trip I would find it very acceptable were the
public notified of a contemplated joint publica
of a Heb. Gram. as a positive thing; and as a thing
not so positive, but dependent upon the support
they extend to the plan—inform them of the
projected issue of the other books named. A
comprehensive good Hebrew Grammar is unquestionably
wanted—we have Nerurtz's? but it is too
large and expensive, Newmans is too meagre
and too badly arranged, all others in the English
language by Jews or Christians for Jewish
schools are in my estimation worth nichts
I have no fear that any of the books I before
referred to will not make their way & expenses
support before hand I do not like to solicit. I
would therefore much like to hear that you

are disposed to make announcement in your next
Occ. that out we will come and that I may be
enabled to withdraw my advertisement from the
Asmonean & supply #c notification of Templo's appear-
ance under altered circumstances. You say you
do not know the books. I could send it you on by express
to look at. It requires a little alteration of arrangement
and will make about 70 pages ?. I think it
a good book so do many others, my brother among them
—but I would of course like your opinion.

I am sorry you were not here Hebrew. I should be
much pleased if next year, D. L. you extend your
visit and come to us. I should be very glad to hear
you read what portion of the prayers you prefer
while in exchange I could myself stand Hebrew
as said the ? lingue of our friend. What I can
do for your Bibles defence I will. I don't know
why the Oc. comes late, but it comes late. Mrs
S? Joseph is sullen? and I believe proposes taking
a trip south. The prayer books being too late
I can be explained by the party's altering his mind
that a set cost “viel geld” and a secondhand one
could be got cheaper—hence the excuse “too late
when Hebrew was only a week off and no books
had arrived. It is not the first time ? have
changed their minds after ordering my fathers'.
I must close though I have more to write
Hoping to hear soon from you I am
